FacilityName: Flint Hills Resources Port Arthur Chemical

_prev_prog_3.CT_OtherType: Completion of Class, Signup Sheet Only
_prev_prog_3.Description: The Light Olefins Unit (LOU) Process has five units which are the Hot Side, Cold Side, GHU/PHU, PDU and LOU Offsites.  The Hot Side includes the furnaces up through the quench columns.  The Cold Side includes compression, refrigeration, and fractionation.  GHU/PHU are two stage gasoline and pyrolysis gasoline hydrogenation units.   The PDU is the propylene drying and transfer units.  LOU Offsites include tankage, waste water stripping unit, flare, custody transfer stations, and loading racks associated with the LOU.  The process controls, mitigations, monitors and detectors listed apply to all units except as follows:  the PDU and LOU Offsites do not have automatic shutoffs; the GHU/PHU and Cold Side are the only units with quench system process controls; only LOU Offsite unit tankage have dikes; the GHU and part of the PHU do not have process area detectors; and fire detectors are only at the PDU, LOU, Compressor Decks, and LOU Lube Oil Skids.  The flammable mixture mass noted below includes inventories of non RMP flammable chemicals and RMP flammable chemicals below the threshold quantity in the process.  RMP chemicals below the threshold quantity included in the flammable mixture are: Acetylene, Ethyl Acetylene, cylohexlamine, Vinylacetate, Hydrogen Sulfide, Carbon Disulfide, and Hydrogen.

_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Demolition of 1" flare connection line that was not in service from a pre-existing analyzer building to Flare K.O. Drum (19C-1).
_prev_prog_3.CT_OtherType: Completion of Class, Signup Sheet Only
_prev_prog_3.Description: The AU/Cyclohexane Process has three units:  UDEX, Cyclohexane and AU/Cyclohexane Offsites.  The UDEX is an aromatics separations unit.  The Cyclohexane Unit manufactures cyclohexane.  The AU/Cyclohexane Offsites includes storage, cooling tower, and flare.  The risk management program's elements for the units listed apply to all units except as follows:  Only the Cyclohexane unit has a quench system; the dikes apply only to storage tanks in the AU/Cyclohexane Unit.  The emergency power and air, automatic shutoffs and purge system do not apply to the AU/Cyclohexane Offsites Unit.  The flammable mixture mass noted below includes inventories of non RMP flammable chemicals and RMP flammable chemicals below the threshold quantity in the process.  RMP chemicals below the threshold quantity included in the flammable mixture are: 1,3 Butadiene; 2-Pentene, (E); 2-Methyl-1-Butene; 2-Pentene (Z); 2 Butene-cis; Butane; Ethane; Isobutane; Methane; Propane, 1-Pentene,  Vinylacetate, and Hydrogen.

_prev_prog_3.Description: PAC Offsites Tankage (two floating roof tanks) located at the Motiva location owned and operated by Flint Hills Resources.  Emergency Response is initiated by Motiva for this site.  The flammable mixture mass noted below includes inventories of non RMP flammable chemicals and RMP flammable chemicals below the threshold quantity in the process.  RMP chemicals below the threshold quantity included in the flammable mixture are: Ethyl Acetylene; Propadiene; Propane; Propyne; Vinyl Acetylene; and Hydrogen.

_accidents.CI_OtherType: Developing system to monitor age and degree of carburization furnace tubes

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
FLINT HILLS RESOURCES - Port Arthur Chemicals (PAC) - EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
 
1.  Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.  Flint Hills Resources Port Arthur Chemicals (PAC) is committed to achieving excellence in environmental, health and safety and anticipates to participate in VPP as a conditional Star Site.  Flint Hills Resources PAC maintains a working Process Safety Management (PSM) program, which implements a series of steps to prevent potential hazards associated with the process and assures a well-trained work force.   The PSM program further implements its policies with onsite procedures and manuals, however FHR has identified the need for improvement in the PSM program and is working to address those improvement areas.  Flint Hills Resources PAC participates with the Jefferson County Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC), Port Arthur Fire Department and the Sabine Neches Chiefs Association to develop emergency response plans and participates in cooperative training with these agencies.  Additionally, Flint Hills Resources PAC participates in the Southeast Texas Alerting Network, STAN, a public awareness system designed to communicate important information to the people of Southeast Texas.  During community emergencies, local emergency management and industrial officials can post information on the STAN line - (877-THE-STAN.)  The Site Manager of PAC is responsible for implementation of the risk management program (RMP).

2.  Regulated Substances.   The PAC Plant employs 178 people and is located on 244.26 acres plus 29.94 acres of shared property with an adjacent industrial complex at the corner of State Highway 73 and Savanna Avenue in Port Arthur, Texas.  The site first opened in 1957 and was acquired in an asset purchase agreement by Flint Hills Resources November, 05, 2008.  The site produces as primary end products ethylene, propylene, cyclohexane and intermediates.  PAC has four processes:  the Light Olefins Unit (LOU) manufac

tures ethylene and propylene; the Aromatics/Cyclohexane Unit manufactures aromatics extract and cyclohexane; Utilities uses chlorine for water treatment; and the offsite tankage area is included in this filing, but adds no additional chemicals other than an increased inventory of existing chemicals.  Flint Hills PAC has twenty-six (26) regulated substances over the threshold quantity at the facility.

Of the Twenty-six (26) regulated substances, twenty-five (25) are flammable as listed:

Ethylene ? Product used to manufacture polyethylene grocery bags, wraps and machine parts, and as a raw material for other ethylene based products (ethylene glycol-antifreeze, ethanol amines-shaving creams, hand lotions, furniture polishes, and dry-cleaning preparations, etc.)

Propylene ? Product used to manufacture polypropylene materials such as films, clothesline and other kinds of rope and, in turn, is used as a raw material for other propylene based materials (propylene glycol-factory fill antifreeze and propylene oxide).

Propane and Ethane - Products recycled to manufacture propylene and ethylene and are ingredients in natural gas.

Methane ? Product used for fuel and is an ingredient of natural gas.

Isobutane, 2-Methyl Propene, Butane, 1-Butene, 1,3-Butadiene, 2-Butene cis and trans, and Vinyl Acetylene - Products used as raw materials in the manufacture of synthetic rubber for tires, and butyl rubber for films, coatings and carpet.

Isopentane, Isoprene, 1-Pentene, 1,3 Pentadiene, 2-Pentene (E) and (Z), 2-Methyl-1-butene, 3-methyl-1-butene, Pentane ? Raw and recycled materials used as feed stocks for the manufacture of ethylene and propylene or sold as a product mix.

Propyne and Propadiene - Intermediates destroyed in downstream reactors.

2,2-Dimethylpropane

The one (1) toxic substance is:

Chlorine - Added to cooling water for treatment
 
3.  General accidental release prevention program and chemical specific prevention steps.  Following is a brief summary of the elem

ents that have been implemented to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements outlined by EPA as well as with the Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.
 
Process Safety Information
A compilation of written safety information to identify and understand the hazards of the process are accessible in the facility.  This includes information pertaining to: 
Hazards of regulated substances:  For each regulated substance, there is a Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) which discusses the physical properties of the chemicals, exposure hazards, the required personal protective equipment and the appropriate first aid and emergency treatment for exposure.
The technology of the process:  Includes a discussion of process chemistry, safe upper and lower limits of temperature and pressure, and analysis of consequences of deviation.

Equipment in the process:  Includes such information as materials of construction, diagrams of the piping and instrumentation, safety systems and design specifications.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)
PHAs are available in the facility files for each process to identify the potential hazards, the adequacy of the engineering and administrative controls and the ways to minimize those hazards.  PAC utilizes the HAZOP methodology, a recognized and generally accepted method for identifying and evaluating hazards in the process.  PAC assigns employees to the HAZOP team who are knowledgeable in the HAZOP methodology and the specific process.  The HAZOP team develops recommendations to reduce the potential hazards.  Approved recommendations are implemented within a reasonable period of time.  Hurricanes and inclement weather are not investigated in the PHAs; however, Flint Hills does have a Hurricane Procedure for PAC and implements this procedure under the threat of a hurricane or inclement weather.
 
Operating Procedures
Written operating procedures that were developed in consultation with

operators to provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities associated with a covered process are accessible.  The procedures address steps for operating phases, safety systems, control measures and precautions to prevent exposures to process hazards.  The procedures are reviewed and revised periodically to ensure their accuracy and completeness.
 
Training
Initial training is provided as well as refresher training to employees to assure that the required level of skills and knowledge are maintained.  The training emphasizes safety and health hazards, emergency operations, and safe work practices.  Operators receive periodic refresher training.  
 
Mechanical Integrity
Written procedures are provided for maintaining the operating components of the process (including pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown system controls, and rotating equipment) through the mechanical integrity program.  The program is comprised of trained personnel who follow maintenance, testing and inspection procedures that ensure proper function of process equipment.
 
Management of Change
Written procedures are provided to manage changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, procedures, and changes to the facility that affect a covered process.  The procedures assure that, prior to change, the following issues are considered:  the technical basis for the proposed change, its impact on safety and health, modification to procedures, the necessary time period for the change, and authorization requirements.  Employees involved in operating a process, as well as maintenance and contract employees whose job will be affected, are informed of and trained in the change.  The process safety information and procedures are updated as necessary.
 
Pre-Startup Review
Pre-startup safety reviews are performed when the addition of or a modification to the facility is made that is significant enough to require a change in the process safet

y information or is deemed as requiring more review than a Management of Change modification.  The pre-startup safety review confirms, prior to the introduction of highly hazardous chemicals, that construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications; safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place; and training of employees affected by modifications is complete.
 
Compliance Audit
Flint Hills PAC performs audits of its compliance with the provisions of its Process Safety Management Program.  Flint Hills Resources accomplishes its compliance audits using a combination of FHR subject matter experts and third party consultants.  These audits are managed by the FHR Corporate Compliance Office and are conducted in three year intervals to verify that the procedures and practices developed are adequate and being followed.  The findings of the audit team are reviewed and corrective actions are implemented.  
 
Incident Investigation
Incidents are investigated that result in, or could reasonably have resulted in, a catastrophic release of covered chemicals.  A report is prepared at the conclusion of the incident investigation that addresses the incident, the factors that contributed to it, and recommendations resulting from the incident investigation.  Flint Hills PAC has established a system to resolve the incident report findings and to document their resolution.  Finally, incident reports are reviewed with affected personnel.
 
Employee Participation
A written action plan for employee participation in Process Safety Management and Risk Management Programs continues to be improved and developed.  Flint Hills PAC consults with employees and their representatives on the conduct and development of PHA?s and on the development of other elements of the Process Safety Management Program.  Flint Hills PAC ensures that employees have access to PHA?s and other process safety management information.
 
Hot Work Permit
Flint Hills PAC employs a h

ot work permit program for hot work operations conducted on or near a covered process.  If hot work is performed on or near a covered process, Flint Hills PAC issues a permit that documents the fire prevention and protection requirements for the operation, the date authorized for hot work, and the object on which the work is performed.
 
Contractors
There are procedures for selecting and ensuring that contractors are competent and knowledgeable and can safely perform their work.  Information is provided to contractors about the hazards that may be present in the work area and has developed appropriate safe work practices.  The safety performance and programs of the contractors are evaluated as a part of their continued employment.
 
4.  Five Year Accident History. One accident in 2006 resulted in significant onsite property damage.  This incident caused the surrounding neighborhood to shelter in place. There were no deaths and one injury of heat exhaustion by a contractor responding to the incident.  On January 21, 2008 a furnace tube ruptured causing a smoking furnace and opacity event resulting in significant onsite property damage. There were no injuries or offsite impacts associated with this incident.  

5.  Emergency Response Program.  A written emergency response program is maintained that contains procedures to be followed in the case of an accidental release of a regulated substance.  These procedures include steps for informing the public, proper first aid and medical treatment, the proper use of emergency equipment and emergency response training for emergency response employees who perform emergency response duties and to local emergency responders who may be called to assist in emergency response.   The emergency response plan is reviewed annually and updated as necessary.  This facility informs local stakeholders about hazardous substances stored and processed on site.  Flint Hills  participates with the Jefferson County LEPC, Sabine Neches Chiefs Asso

ciation and Port Arthur Fire Department  in assisting local officials in the development of emergency procedures to identify resources, chemicals, contacts and material safety data sheets for participating companies.  The Incident Commander is the emergency contact in the event of an emergency.
 
6.  Planned changes to improve safety.   There are several planned improvements at PAC to reduce the on and offsite impacts.  PAC continues to upgrade the Safety Instrumented Systems (SIS) to current ISA 84 Standards.  There is an ongoing commitment to implement changes that will improve the safety of employees and neighbors of the PAC Plant as well as projects that enhance safety, environmental protection and minimize exposure to accidental releases.
